body: Any chance we can do this in a way that the old jackson provider remains, and a new Johnzon provider is added?  It looks like the johnzon dependency should be test scoped since all of the relevant tamaya code is based on javax.json.
javax.json.\* is only the API (JSR 353) without implementation. So Johnzon (which is the implementation) have to be also in the runtime classpath. Jackson does not implement javax.json JSR 353 API.

I will look at the patch later here, and if it looks good (what I assume) I
will update the repo. In general using the standardized API makes for me
more sense then relying on a third party API, especially also for later use
as part of any kind of container that already provides the required API and
impl as part of the container infrastructure ;)

Best,
Anatole

2015-08-16 15:15 GMT+02:00 Hendrik Saly notifications@github.com:

> javax.json.\* is only the API (JSR 353) without implementation. So Johnzon
> (which is the implementation) have to be also in the runtime classpath.
> Jackson does not implement javax.json JSR 353 API.
> 
> —

2016-11-21 15:55 GMT+01:00 Christian Schneider <notifications@github.com>:

> The current OSGi config is quite verbose and relies on packaging bundle.
> In this PR I switch to using the bnd-maven-plugin and try to minimize the
> required config.
>
> The needed settings per bundle are defined in bnd.bnd files which have a
> simple syntax. Bndtools also provides a nice editor for these files but it
> is not required.
> Apart from that the individual projects then need no special setup in the
> pom.
> ------------------------------
> You can view, comment on, or merge this pull request online at:
>
>   https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/pull/8
> Commit Summary
>
>    - Use bnd-maven-plugin. Minimize required config
>
> File Changes
>
>    - *A* code/api/bnd.bnd
>    <https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/pull/8/files#diff-0> (3)
>    - *M* code/api/pom.xml
>    <https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/pull/8/files#diff-1> (34)

I've refactored this to use LinkedHashSets instead of ArrayLists in the 2 places I was worried about.  I think that covers what was discussed on the mailing list?
Thanks for the PR - could you provide a little more context? What does adding the annotation-package fix or improve? Thanks

Thanks for your contribution @acoburn - the tests seem to be in disorder concerning the order of assertions. Can you do a mass-replaceFindAll to use more easier AssertJ-assertions in some cases? This would be great. :1st_place_medal:

@acoburn I'll merge the pull request please feel free to open a new one with the exception things.


I do still see errors in the log such as:

    java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.tamaya.core.internal.DefaultConfiguration not found by org.apache.tamaya.core

and 

    java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.tamaya.core.internal.CoreConfigurationContextBuilder not found by org.apache.tamaya.core

and

    java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.tamaya.core.internal.ConfigValueEvaluator not found by org.apache.tamaya.core

But perhaps those changes are part of #41 (TAMAYA-381) -- they are just due to the `META-INF/services` values pointing to the wrong class names. Should both of those commits be merged to see the correct behavior?
Yup, this PR makes the bundles activate-able, and #41 cleans up the errors from mis-pointed service providers.

@acoburn a local run with the following parameters goes through:
`
mvn clean org.jacoco:jacoco-maven-plugin:prepare-agent install sonar:sonar \
  -Dsonar.projectKey=apache_incubator-tamaya \
  -Dsonar.organization=apache \
  -Dsonar.host.url=https://sonarcloud.io \
  -Dsonar.login=<TOKEN_GENERATED/SHOULD BE THE SAME AS $SONAR_TOKEN>
`

Now the error is: `Project 'apache:apache_incubator-tamaya' can't have 2 modules with the following key: apache:apache_incubator-tamaya`. I recall seeing something like that before, but I'll need to investigate. At least it's connecting to SonarCloud now.

@ottlinger I've tried a number of permutations using the configurations suggested here. I still see test failures, but the latest is

`You're not authorized to run analysis. Please contact the project administrator.`

which seems like an issue either with the token configured in Travis-CI or with the project org/key not lining up with the Sonar project identifiers.

The latest version of this PR puts all of the sonar-related configuration/overrides into the `.travis.yml` file. If, @ottlinger, you are able to run that same command locally with the sonar token, then perhaps there is something wrong with the token value configured in Travis-CI? That is, maybe regenerating the token would help?

@bellingard thanks so much for the suggestions. The strange thing is that, despite using Travis' sonar add-on, without specifying the `sonar.host.url` (either in the Maven command in `.travis.yml` or in this file here) the `sonar:sonar` stage tries to connect to a `localhost` address. It seems that, perhaps, the add-on isn't registering properly. In fact, when looking at the raw Travis-CI log, I don't see any indication that the sonarcloud add-on is actually getting initiated. (In other projects of mine that use the sonarcloud add-on, I definitely see indication of this in the logs).

@acoburn running the analysis locally still works ok:

* :green_book:  no maven warnings
* build failures:

```
org.apache.tamaya.ext:tamaya-mutable-config:jar:0.3-incubating-SNAPSHOT, org.apache.tamaya:tamaya-api:jar:0.3-incubating-SNAPSHOT,
```

I think we should consider moving this example project to the `tamaya-extensions` repository. This particular example depends on `org.apache.tamaya.ext/tamaya-injection-api` (among others). Even if those dependencies are addressed, imagine what would happen during a release (e.g. 0.4.0): one would first need to `mvn install -pl '!:tamaya-example-distributed'` on the core repository, then `mvn install` on the extensions repository and only _then_ can one run `mvn verify` (i.e. with this example) on the core repository.

Moving this to `tamaya-extensions` would eliminate the circular dependency.
@acoburn I'm in favour of your proposal .... and remember a discussion to create a new repo tamaya-examples .... but moving it into extensions to get rid of the circular deps makes sense to me.

@acoburn Argh, I know why it could not work in this PR: this is because it originates from a fork (`acoburn:sonar`) and Travis CI won't activate the SonarCloud extension on "external PR" builds for security reasons (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/sonarcloud/#analysis-of-internal-pull-requests).
@bellingard ahh, that makes sense. I should have started by pushing this branch to the main repo and not my own fork. It seems to be working now, so thanks so much for your assistance!

My pleasure @acoburn. :)
Note that I tool a look at the Travis YML on master, and looks like it's not correct (maybe some merge issues). I added a comment on https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/commit/98bc730a4dbfd257fef02abf59c7f31397e1abef. This is very easy to fix.

@ottlinger I noticed that, too. I think the issue is that Travis-CI didn't seem to receive the webhook from github. If Travis-CI isn't triggered, then the Sonar analysis won't get run. Do you have access to the Webhooks menu for this repo? i.e. https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/settings/hooks/. Sometimes it's possible to re-send a webhook in order to trigger a new CI analysis.
I'm unable to access above URL .... https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/settings/hooks/ gives a 404 (maybe related to the way ASF repos are synced with Github).

mmmh - strange. My commit from yesterday did not yet trigger a Travis rebuild.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/commit/85b3aae11cb10f7c95f625636e8c3c2c7c075510
Not sure if volatile has any meaning in the OSGi world, but we'll definitely find out 👍

@ottlinger the best way to test OSGi is with Pax-Exam, but that adds a huge amount of complexity and should probably be part of a separate effort. In the meantime, though, I can definitely add some simple tests.

... or we merge the changes although they break the quality build:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/pull/49/checks?check_run_id=116131187

Do you see a chance to reduce the duplicate-warning? I tried to extract the stuff into a method, but that only made things worse.

I suppose the question is whether Sonar non-compliance should be allowed to fail a build or not. I personally find Sonar to be very useful, but I typically put it in a `after_success` clause like this:

```
script: mvn clean install 
after_success: mvn sonar:sonar -Dsonar.organization=apache -Dsonar.projectKey=apache_incubator-tamaya
```
@ottlinger all the checks now pass.

@acoburn thanks - my IDE marked the first lines in
* processEntryPath(Bundle bundle, String entryPath)
* removeEntryPath(Bundle bundle, String entryPath)
as possible duplicates. Your solution is much simpler and does not break the quality build.

Thanks :+1:
I pushed this to my own fork, which results in a failed sonar analysis (as @peculater mentioned earlier). I can also close this and re-do the PR from the apache repo itself, if that would be better.
Can you do this apart from your fork? Would it change if we moved the Sonar analysis to the after-success-part? I guess not, right ....

I believe that after merging the two PRs above (https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya-extensions/pull/38 and https://github.com/apache/incubator-tamaya/pull/55) this PR can be closed based on the comments above.
Thanks @peculater - can you close the TAMAYA-386 in jira as well.
Not sure if this revapi-stuff does not break the build as I assume we had a lot of API changes, but let's see :+1:
